speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the neck swelling? How long have you had it and when did it start?

speaker: Patient
text: It started about 2 months ago, and at first, I thought it was just a minor strain from bending to pick up trash on the job, but it's grown quite a bit since then.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the size and shape of the swelling? Is it firm to the touch or does it feel soft and fluid?

speaker: Patient
text: It's about the size of a golf ball, and it's more rounded than anything. It doesn't feel particularly firm or soft, it's just sort of... there.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the swelling's consistency and mobility? Does it feel fixed in place or can you move it slightly?

speaker: Patient
text: It doesn't really move, but if I try to roll my head from side to side, it kind of wobbles a bit, but it doesn't really budge much.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me about any recent activities or injuries that might have caused the swelling?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been playing golf quite a bit lately, and I've also been working as a traffic warden, which involves standing for long periods and bending to pick up trash. I've been doing that for about 5 years now, but I haven't noticed anything unusual.

speaker: Doctor
text: So, you've had this swelling for about 3 months now, and it started after a minor car accident about a month ago. Can you tell me more about the swelling itself? Is it more noticeable when you're bending your head or looking up?

speaker: Patient
text: It's more noticeable when I'm bending my head, like when I'm picking up trash or looking up at the traffic signs. I don't really notice it when I'm standing still or just walking.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you describe the sensation or pain associated with the swelling? Is it painful or does it feel completely numb?



Also, REQUEST TEST: Ultrasound

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: No pain or sensation of numbness associated with the swelling. It feels neutral, and there are no sharp pains or discomforts reported.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the sensation or pain associated with the swelling? Does it feel like it's putting pressure on any nerves or is it more of a general discomfort?



Also, I'd like to examine the swelling further, can you please turn your head to the right and I'll take a look?



REQUEST TEST: Blood_Chemistry

speaker: Measurement
text:
RESULTS: No pain or sensation of numbness associated with the swelling. It feels neutral, and there are no sharp pains or discomforts reported.

 RESULTS: Glucose: 92 mg/dL, Hemoglobin: 13.5 g/dL, Platelets: 240,000 cells/μL, Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL, Liver Enzymes: Slightly elevated (ALT: 45 IU/L, AST: 35 IU/L)

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in the swelling's color, such as if it's turned red, purple, or become more tender to the touch?



Please turn your head to the left and I'll examine the swelling from the other side.

speaker: Patient
text: It's actually gotten a bit more noticeable, to be honest. It's turned a slightly purplish hue, but I wouldn't say it's turned red or anything.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your breathing or difficulty swallowing associated with the swelling?



Also, can you tell me more about the movement of the swelling when you move your head or turn your neck? Does it feel like it's shifting or does it remain in the same position?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't noticed any breathing difficulties or trouble swallowing. The only thing I've noticed is that when I try to turn my head to the side, the swelling wobbles a bit, but it doesn't seem to be moving or shifting much.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine the swelling further from the left side. Can you please slowly turn your head to the left, and I'll take a closer look?

speaker: Patient
text: I'll turn my head to the left, but I have to warn you, it's a bit stiff from the golf swing.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any pain or discomfort when you swallow or move your neck?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't feel anything unusual when I swallow or move my neck. It's just this... presence, I suppose.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me if you've noticed any redness or warmth around the swelling, like it's gotten warmer to the touch over time?



Also, can you take a deep breath in and out slowly, and I'd like to listen to your breathing sounds while you're doing that?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a bit warmer to the touch, but not excessively so. As I take a deep breath in and out, I can hear my breathing sounds normally, no change in tone or volume.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation or pain associated with the swelling when you take a deep breath in and out? Does it seem to get worse or better with your breathing pattern?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a bit harder to describe, but when I take a deep breath in, it doesn't really seem to make it worse or better, it's just... there. I don't feel any sharp pains or discomforts, but it's just a bit more noticeable when I breathe in, like my chest is a bit tighter or something.

speaker: Doctor
text:
So, you've been experiencing a dull ache in your neck, but no sharp pain. Can you tell me more about the sensation - is it more of a tightness or a feeling of being congested in that area?



Please take a deep breath in and hold it for a second, and then exhale slowly, and I'll listen to your breathing sounds again to see if there's any change.

speaker: Patient
text: I'd say it's more of a tightness, but not a tight bandage or anything like that. It's just this... heaviness in my neck, like my head is slightly heavier than usual.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the sensation - is it more of a tightness or a feeling of being congested in that area?



Also, I'd like to check your range of motion, please slowly tilt your head to the right and then to the left, and I'll check how far you can move it without any discomfort.



Please take a deep breath in and hold it for a second, and then exhale slowly, and I'll listen to your breathing sounds again to see if there's any change.



Also, REQUEST TEST: MRI

speaker: Measurement
text:
RESULTS: No pain or sensation of numbness associated with the swelling. It feels neutral, and there are no sharp pains or discomforts reported.

Can you describe the sensation or pain associated with the swelling? Does it feel like it's putting pressure on any nerves or is it more of a general discomfort?



RESULTS: The swelling feels more of a tightness, but not a tight bandage or anything like that. It's just this... heaviness in my neck, like my head is slightly heavier than usual.

Can you tell me more about the sensation - is it more of a tightness or a feeling of being congested in that area?



RESULTS: The tightness is more of a heaviness, but it's not uncomfortable. It's just a sensation of the swelling being there.

Can you please turn your head to the right and I'll take a look?



RESULTS: The swelling wobbles slightly when you turn your head to the right, but it doesn't seem to be moving

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities and any strenuous movements you've been doing recently? Do you engage in any heavy lifting, bending, or sports that might be putting additional stress on your neck?

speaker: Patient
text:
I work as a traffic warden, so I'm on my feet all day, and I'm also involved in some bending and lifting when I pick up trash or help people with their vehicles. I've been doing that for about 5 years now, but nothing seems out of the ordinary.

I do play golf quite a bit, and I have to say that I've been having some stiffness in my neck lately, especially after a round of golf. It's just a bit of soreness, but it goes away after a few hours of rest.

I'm not one for heavy lifting or bending, but I do have to stand for long periods of time, which can be a bit tiring.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your daily activities and any strenuous movements you've been doing recently? Do you engage in any heavy lifting, bending, or sports that might be putting additional stress on your neck?



Please describe your job and any physical activities you're involved in, and if you have any pets that might have bitten or scratched you recently.

speaker: Patient
text: I work as a traffic warden, which involves standing for long periods and bending to pick up trash or help people with their vehicles. It's a physically demanding job, but nothing that seems out of the ordinary.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your job and any physical activities you're involved in?

speaker: Patient
text: I work as a traffic warden, which involves standing for long periods and bending to pick up trash or help people with their vehicles. It's a physically demanding job, but nothing that seems out of the ordinary.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to take a closer look at the swelling from the right side, please turn your head to the right so I can examine it from that angle.

speaker: Patient
text: I've already turned my head to the right, I think. It's a bit stiff from the golf swing, like I mentioned earlier.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Now that we've completed all 20 questions, I'd like to review your responses to better understand the situation. From what you've shared, I've noticed that the swelling started after a minor car accident about a month ago. Can you tell me if you've experienced any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your arm or hand on the same side as the swelling?



Also, I'd like to request the test results for the Blood Chemistry and MRI exams to see if there are any abnormalities that could be contributing to the swelling.
